TICKETS FOR DANCE
SELLING RAPIDLY
Tickets to the Military Ball
are being sold rapidly, according to the committee in charge
of the affair. The ball is open
only to members of the-R. 0.
T. C. Unit, either active or
alumni.
Special care is being taken
to make the dance a success
in every particular. Bob Iula
will, in person, direct his
orchestra. T h e subscription
price is $1 stag or couple and
the dance will be held Friday
night in Levering Hall.

John Mount was winner of the
Adams Declamation Contest held
Thursday, March 6, in assembly.
His pasage was "My Native Land,"
which was delivered by Washington
Irving upon his return from an extended stay in Europe. Yudkin,
Harris and Brook were the runnersup, in the order named.

by the late Prof. Herbert B. Adams.

RESTORATION OF MANSION TO
ORIGINAL FORM REVIVES INTEREST
Reports, unofficially circulated,
that the restored Carroll Mansion
will be opened sometime in April,
revive interest in the old building
which has served the architects of
the Hopkins buildings as their model. The structure has been associated
with the University and artistic life
of the city for a number of years.
All during the present academic
year, the operations of restoration
have been in progress. Mr. Halstead,
who performed similar services for
the commodious basement, where
several rooms were fitted with open
fireplaces and showers were set up,
the installation of electric lights, and
the connection of the mansion with
the central heating system of the
University.

Georgian houses" and further characterized it as having "a perfectly
proportional hallway."
Harwood House in Annapolis, is
doing the work. Among the most
conspicuous changes has been the
substitution of a slate for the old
tin roof. The intention is to use the
mansion as a museum of colonial
furniture and art objects.

J. H. U. NATATORS
TO MEET GETTYSBURG
Tonight at 8 o'clock the
J o h n s Hopkins swimming
team meets Gettysburg College
at the Knights of Columbus
pool.
This will be the fourth
match of the season, the other
three were with Delaware, Y.
M. C. A. and Gettysburg. The
team this year has been able to
make but little progress, due
largely to the fact that very
few men have turned out. Although the other three matches
were all defeats, the last was
very close and it is expected
that tonight will bring a victory. Price of admission is 50
cents or 25 cents with the A.
A. ticket.

RELATIONS RENEWED
WITH TERROR TEAMS
Western Maryland And Jays
To Again Meet
END 7-YEAR BREAK
Tennis To Be First In Which
Teams Engage
Hopkins and Western Maryland
have renewed athletic relations, according to the athletic office. The
renewal of affiliations in sports
comes after a seven-year period in
which the teams or representatives
of neither institution met.
The new pact is the result of an
attempt to 'bring together again the
two state colleges and end one of
the longest standing breaks of any
two colleges in Maryland.

to the washing machine
Cheaper power! Groping after this modern
touchstone to wealth, deluded inventors slaved
over perpetual motion machines ... informed
inventors evolved the turbine...broad visioned
men harnessed the rush of waters ... engineers
raised pressures and temperatures to produce
more power without corresponding increases
of cost.
While, step by step, this progress has taken
place, the many men who have contributed to
it could not know what far-reaching results it
would have. Now the ultimate boons grow
clear. Water power development becomes a
national policy, steam bids fair to rival water
power for cheapness, economically produced
power brings more plentiful goods,lights houses
and hauls crowds in cities, is carried to rural
sections to lift washday drudgery from farm
women's shoulders.
Among the many industrial victories that are
behind this revolution, none is more important
than wider knowledge of piping materials and
better materials. One of the highly prized
chapters of our history is the contribution that
Crane research and valve engineering has made
to the general advance. The results of this
research are embodied in a Crane book,Pioneering in Science. It is a fascinating story of engineering development and a valuable reference
work for engineering students. A request will
bring you a copy.

RESTORATION OF MANSION TO
ORIGINAL FORM REVIVES INTEREST
Reports, unofficially circulated,
that the restored Carroll Mansion
will be opened sometime in April,
revive interest in the old building
which has served the architects of
the Hopkins buildings as their model. The structure has been associated
with the University and artistic life
of the city for a number of years.
All during the present academic
year, the operations of restoration
have been in progress. Mr. Halstead,
who performed similar services for
the commodious basement, where
several rooms were fitted with open
fireplaces and showers were set up,
the installation of electric lights, and
the connection of the mansion with
the central heating system of the
University.

Georgian houses" and further characterized it as having "a perfectly
proportional hallway."
Harwood House in Annapolis, is
doing the work. Among the most
conspicuous changes has been the
substitution of a slate for the old
tin roof. The intention is to use the
mansion as a museum of colonial
furniture and art objects.

J. H. U. NATATORS
TO MEET GETTYSBURG
Tonight at 8 o'clock the
J o h n s Hopkins swimming
team meets Gettysburg College
at the Knights of Columbus
pool.
This will be the fourth
match of the season, the other
three were with Delaware, Y.
M. C. A. and Gettysburg. The
team this year has been able to
make but little progress, due
largely to the fact that very
few men have turned out. Although the other three matches
were all defeats, the last was
very close and it is expected
that tonight will bring a victory. Price of admission is 50
cents or 25 cents with the A.
A. ticket.

to the washing machine
Cheaper power! Groping after this modern
touchstone to wealth, deluded inventors slaved
over perpetual motion machines ... informed
inventors evolved the turbine...broad visioned
men harnessed the rush of waters ... engineers
raised pressures and temperatures to produce
more power without corresponding increases
of cost.
While, step by step, this progress has taken
place, the many men who have contributed to
it could not know what far-reaching results it
would have. Now the ultimate boons grow
clear. Water power development becomes a
national policy, steam bids fair to rival water
power for cheapness, economically produced
power brings more plentiful goods,lights houses
and hauls crowds in cities, is carried to rural
sections to lift washday drudgery from farm
women's shoulders.
Among the many industrial victories that are
behind this revolution, none is more important
than wider knowledge of piping materials and
better materials. One of the highly prized
chapters of our history is the contribution that
Crane research and valve engineering has made
to the general advance. The results of this
research are embodied in a Crane book,Pioneering in Science. It is a fascinating story of engineering development and a valuable reference
work for engineering students. A request will
bring you a copy.
